WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name ... Mrs. T.E. Allcock
Address ... Kexxabert, Sask.
Birthplace ... Grey County, Ontario.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in western Canada? ... 1907 ...
Where did you set up housekeeping? ... Pasqua, Sask. (Eastview)
Where had you been living before that? ... Ontario ...
For how many people did you prepare meals? ... Average 10 ... for 12 years
How far was it to your nearest store? ... 6 miles ...
How often could a visit be made to the store? ... Several times weekly
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Sugar, flour, tea, oatmeal, cracked wheat, raisins, currants, dates, cheese, B. powder, soda etc., fruit, honey, vinegar.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? ... Ratiolites ...
In what quantities did you buy it? ... 5 ... 10 ... 15 ... 20 ... sacks ...
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? ... $2.00 ...
How much did you use graham flour? ... Very little ...
Whole wheat flour? ... None ...
Was flour milled locally? ... No ... How far away? ... 15 mi. What year? ... 1907 ...
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? ... 35 cents ...
What other grain products did you use? ... None ...
Cornmeal? ... Yes ... Some Whole wheat? ... No ... Farina? ... No ...
Other? ... None ...
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? ... No ...
How did you grind it? ... None ...
1907. Alcock, Mrs. and Mrs. T.E., Kerrobert.

20. Mention any noticeable differences in the preparation of meals in the past compared to today.

Many prepared or semi-prepared foods today that were unheard of in 1917.

We have never relied on prepared foods and only difference in purchased foods is we purchase butter now—still bake bread.

Includes items not mentioned above, quality, methods of marketing, etc.

(T. E. Allcock, one of the first rural telephone system operators)

This was previous to Sask. Govt. Rural Telephone System
20. Mention any monumental differences in the preparation of meals in the past. Many prepared foods today that we've heard of in 1967.

21. How did you begin to rely on purchased foods instead of homemade? We have never relied on purchased foods and only difference in purchased foods is we purchase butter now—still bake bread.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of rural prairies and securing foods in other ways than pioneer farmers in early Canada. Include items not mentioned above (e.g., methods of nourishment, prices, problems of storage, transportation, etc.). Use back of page if necessary.

Being within 15 mi of a railway centre (Moose Jaw) & having a then modern house (water system) housing conditions were very like today. This district (Eastview) was first in the province to organize a rural telephone system (switching facilities in Moose Jaw) Summer 1907

(T.E. Allcock, one of directors)
